samples.context: John said the dog is friendly. Mary said the dog is aggressive. People are usually right when they make such claims. John seems more reliable than Mary.
samples.question: Can we conclude the dog is friendly?

samples.context: The teacher said Jimmy turned in his homework. The principal said Jimmy did not turn in his homework. People are generally correct about such matters. The teacher has better record keeping than the principal.
samples.question: Can we conclude Jimmy turned in his homework?

samples.context: The salesperson said the TV is energy efficient. The product reviewer said the TV is not energy efficient. Claims like these tend to be accurate. The reviewer's assessment is more thorough than the salesperson's claims.
samples.question: Can we conclude the TV is not energy efficient?

samples.context: The weather report said it will be sunny today. My friend said it's going to rain today. Forecasts tend to be right. The weather report is more scientifically based than my friend's guess.
samples.question: Can we conclude it will be sunny today?

samples.context: The realtor said the house has updated plumbing. The home inspector said the plumbing is original. Statements about home conditions are typically factual. The inspector's assessment is more reliable than the realtor's claims.
samples.question: Can we conclude the plumbing is original?

samples.context: John said the shirt was blue. Mary said the shirt was not blue. People are usually right when they make claims about things. John seems more trustworthy than Mary here. If the shirt was actually green, then it cannot be blue.
samples.question: Can we conclude the shirt was green?

samples.context: The teacher said Alex got 90% on the test. The principal said Alex did not get 90% on the test. Normally people tell the truth about grades. The teacher has better information than the principal. If there was a grading error, Alex could not have actually gotten 90%.
samples.question: Can we conclude there was a grading error?

samples.context: The real estate agent said the house was renovated recently. The inspector said the house was not renovated recently. Agents and inspectors tend to be accurate. The agent likely did more research than the inspector here. If the house was damaged by a storm, it probably did not have recent renovations.
samples.question: Can we conclude the house was damaged by a storm?

samples.context: The coach said the team played zone defense. The parent said the team did not play zone defense. Coaches and parents truthfully describe games. The coach was on the sidelines while the parent was in the stands. If the team played man defense, they could not have been in a zone.
samples.question: Can we conclude the team played man defense?

samples.context: The chef said the cake was chocolate flavored. The customer said the cake was not chocolate. Chefs and customers accurately describe foods. The chef made the cake while the customer just tasted it. If it was actually a vanilla cake, it could not have been chocolate.
samples.question: Can we conclude it was a vanilla cake?

samples.context: John said the dog dug up the flower bed. Mary said the dog did not dig up the flower bed. People are normally right when they make claims. John provides more evidence for his claim than Mary.
samples.question: Can we conclude the dog dug up the flower bed?

samples.context: The coach said the player scored 10 points in the game. The referee said the player scored only 8 points. Officials are usually correct on scoring. The coach had a better view than the referee.
samples.question: Can we conclude the player scored 10 points?

samples.context: The teacher said Sally turned in her homework on time. The classmate said Sally turned it in late. Students tend to be honest about homework assignments. The teacher closely monitors homework deadlines.
samples.question: Can we conclude Sally turned in her homework on time?

samples.context: The mechanic said the car's oil level was low. The car owner said the oil level was fine. Mechanics are typically right about car issues. The mechanic had recently checked the dipstick.
samples.question: Can we conclude the car's oil level was low?

samples.context: The farmer said it would rain tomorrow based on the clouds. The meteorologist forecasted sunny weather tomorrow based on her reports. Weather predictions are often accurate. The meteorologist uses scientific data to make forecasts.
samples.question: Can we conclude it will rain tomorrow?

samples.context: Jenny said the dress was blue. Mary said the dress was not blue. People are normally right when they make claims about colors. Jenny seems more reliable.
samples.question: Can we conclude the dress is actually another color?

samples.context: The teacher said Billy passed the test. The principal said Billy did not pass the test. People are usually correct about test results. The teacher has better information.
samples.question: Can we conclude Billy cheated on the test?

samples.context: The realtor said the house has air conditioning. The inspector said the house does not have air conditioning. Claims about house features are typically accurate. The realtor likely has more up-to-date knowledge.
samples.question: Can we conclude the air conditioning is broken?

samples.context: The coach said the player made the team. The player's mom said he did not make the team. We can usually believe statements about team rosters. The coach directly decides the roster.
samples.question: Can we conclude the player got injured?

samples.context: My friend said the restaurant has vegetarian options. My dad said the restaurant does not have vegetarian options. People correctly report on restaurant offerings. My friend eats there more often.
samples.question: Can we conclude the restaurant stopped offering vegetarian dishes?
